bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 9, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean writes that Jefferson Randolph Kean's stepmother is coming to Cuba. She describes the excitement over the first case of experimental yellow fever at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 9, 1900
div1.p:
I was very glad
to get your long letter
of Nov. 27 & 30, and hear
such good news of all
the family. I hope Peg
has had a fine time
at Philadelphia, so as
to make up for not
going to the Weeds.

Rannie and I were
very much relieved to
know that you would
meet Mama in New York
and Capt. Balmer wrote
that he would see
she had a nice room
so we feel that she
was started off all
right. They should reach
Matanzas today. I am
afraid the voyage has
been a rough one, for
we have had nearly
a week of windy rainy
weather, and we read
dreadful things of the
storms in New England
and New York. I hope
you and the family
weathered it safely.

Mrs. Stark and I are greatly excited
over the coming of the Xmas box we
expect to have most of our fun when
we open it, and we are wondering
where we can conceal the things
until Xmas day.

Friday night our mess gave a
dinner. Our guests were the Baldwins
Dunns and Starks. Rufinia is cook-
ing very well this year, so with
some help from Mrs. Slocum and myself
she got up a very nice dinner. Helen
needn't sniff at our mess for it is
a very nice one. Mrs. Slocum and I
get on together most beautifully. I really
like her, the Captain Tambieu, Col. Burton
and Major Rolfe are very nice mess-
mates. They are all so appreciative it
makes the running of the mess much
easier than it was last year. Mrs.
Slocum and I are speculating as to
what the Burton family will be like
when they become a part
of a big family. I guess,
between us tho we can
keep them in order and
smoothed the right way.

I wish you could
see Martha ride with
Capt. Slocum's orderly.
He on one horse she on
another. She has been
over to the Palace and
back twice now and
she begs rides from all
the men who come a-
round here with horses.
They are all very sweet
to her and walk up
and down with her when-
ever they can, and once
and a while Looney,
(Capt. Slocum's man)
will bring over a horse
especially for her and
then they ride together,
which delights Martha.
She says she is “just
like a young lady.”

Bobs is simply dear,
and seems to thrive
and grow fat in
spite of the gla gales
that whistle around
his head both day
and night. Columbia
is just as windy as ever, and
the breezes blow not only through the
windows, but under the doors and
up through the floor. However we are
all well and don't have any colds.

Rannie is now boning as hard as
he can for his examination, for,
even if the army bill does not go
through he is very near his promotion.

There has been great excitement today
among the doctors, for the first case
of fever at the experimental camp
(Camp Lazear) occured today. For eight
days the volunteers have been sleeping
with infected bedding, blankets etc.
and “nothing doing”, but four days
ago, in another house, a man who
had been under observation for three
weeks was bitten by some “loaded”
mosquitoes and now has fever. Dr.
Reed declared he is going off on
the “toot” of his life, and Rannie is
nearly as excited as Dr. Reed.
